test_cases.title: Verify Patient Data at Rest Encryption (AES-256)
test_cases.description: This test case verifies that all patient data stored in the database is encrypted using AES-256, ensuring compliance with HIPAA Security Rule requirements for protecting electronic Protected Health Information (ePHI) at rest.

test_steps.action: Log in to the application as a clinician and create a new patient record with identifiable PHI.
test_steps.input_data: Patient Name: 'John Doe', DOB: '1980-01-15', MRN: 'MRN12345', Diagnosis: 'Hypertension'
test_steps.expected_result: The patient record is successfully created and saved in the system.

test_steps.action: Access the database directly using a database administration tool (requires elevated privileges).
test_steps.expected_result: Successful connection to the database.

test_steps.action: Locate the table containing patient records and query the record created in Step 1.
test_steps.input_data: SQL Query: SELECT * FROM patients WHERE mrn = 'MRN12345';
test_steps.expected_result: The query returns the row for the patient. The columns containing PHI (e.g., name, dob, diagnosis) display as unintelligible, encrypted text, not 'John Doe' or 'Hypertension'.

test_steps.action: Review the database configuration settings to confirm the encryption algorithm used.
test_steps.input_data: Database configuration files or admin console.
test_steps.expected_result: The database configuration explicitly states that Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) or equivalent column-level encryption is enabled using the AES-256 algorithm.

test_data.test_environment: Staging environment with database admin access.
test_data.data_cleanup: Delete the test patient record 'MRN12345' from the application UI. Verify deletion in the database.

prerequisites: Database administration tools are installed and accessible.
A test user with clinician privileges exists.
The database schema and table names are known.

expected_results.primary_result: Patient data stored in the database is confirmed to be encrypted with AES-256 and is unreadable without decryption keys.
verification_criteria: Direct database queries show encrypted, not plaintext, PHI.
Database configuration confirms AES-256 encryption is active.

pass_criteria: All PHI fields in the database are shown as encrypted strings.
Database settings confirm the use of AES-256.
fail_criteria: Any PHI field is stored in plaintext in the database.
The encryption algorithm is not AES-256 or is not enabled.
post_conditions: The test patient record is removed from the system.

regulatory_requirements: HIPAA Security Rule § 164.312(a)(2)(iv) - Encryption and Decryption (Addressable)
ISO 27001 Annex A.10.1 - Cryptographic Controls
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Screenshot of the database query result showing encrypted data. Screenshot of the database configuration showing AES-256 is enabled. A signed test execution report.

test_cases.title: Verify Data in Transit Encryption (TLS 1.3)
test_cases.description: This test case verifies that all data transmitted between the client application and the server is encrypted using TLS 1.3, protecting PHI from interception and ensuring compliance with HIPAA.

test_steps.action: Start a network traffic analysis tool (e.g., Wireshark) on the client machine to capture network packets.
test_steps.input_data: Filter for traffic to/from the application server's IP address.
test_steps.expected_result: Wireshark begins capturing packets.

test_steps.action: Using a web browser, log in to the application and access a patient's record.
test_steps.expected_result: The user successfully logs in and the patient's data is displayed on the screen.

test_steps.action: Stop the packet capture in Wireshark.
test_steps.expected_result: Packet capture is stopped.

test_steps.action: Analyze the captured traffic. Filter for the 'TLS' protocol and inspect the 'Client Hello' and 'Server Hello' messages.
test_steps.expected_result: The TLS handshake is observed. The protocol version negotiated is TLS 1.3.

test_steps.action: Inspect the application data packets within the TLS stream.
test_steps.expected_result: The payload of the packets is shown as 'Encrypted Application Data'. No plaintext PHI (e.g., patient name, MRN) is visible in the packet capture.

test_data.test_environment: Staging environment with a client machine that has Wireshark (or similar) installed.
test_data.data_cleanup: No data cleanup required.

prerequisites: A network traffic analysis tool is installed on the client machine.
A test user with clinician privileges exists.
The IP address of the application server is known.

expected_results.primary_result: All communication between the client and server is confirmed to be encrypted using TLS 1.3.
verification_criteria: Network traffic analysis shows the negotiated protocol is TLS 1.3.
No PHI is transmitted in plaintext over the network.

pass_criteria: The TLS version is 1.3.
Application data packets are encrypted and unreadable.
fail_criteria: The TLS version is older than 1.3 (e.g., TLS 1.2, 1.1, SSL).
Any PHI is visible in plaintext in the network capture.
post_conditions: User is logged out of the application.

regulatory_requirements: HIPAA Security Rule § 164.312(e)(1) - Transmission Security (Addressable)
FIPS 140-2 for cryptographic modules.
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Screenshots from Wireshark showing the TLS 1.3 handshake and the encrypted application data payload. A signed test execution report.

test_cases.title: Verify Account Lockout After 5 Failed Login Attempts
test_cases.description: This negative test case verifies that the system enforces the account lockout policy by locking a user's account after 5 consecutive failed login attempts. This is a critical security control to prevent brute-force attacks.

test_steps.action: Navigate to the application login page.
test_steps.expected_result: The login page is displayed.

test_steps.action: Attempt to log in 5 consecutive times with a valid username but an invalid password.
test_steps.expected_result: For the first 4 attempts, an 'Invalid username or password' error message is displayed. On the 5th attempt, a different message is displayed, such as 'Your account has been locked due to too many failed login attempts. Please contact support.'

test_steps.action: Attempt to log in a 6th time, this time using the correct password.
test_steps.expected_result: Access is denied. The 'Account is locked' message persists.

test_steps.action: Log in as an administrator and navigate to the user management section.
test_steps.expected_result: The user management page is displayed.

test_steps.action: Locate the user 'lockout_user_test' and verify their account status.
test_steps.expected_result: The user's account status is displayed as 'Locked' or 'Inactive'.

test_steps.action: Check the audit log for the failed login attempts and lockout event.
test_steps.expected_result: The audit log contains 5 entries for 'Failed Login' and one entry for 'Account Locked' for the user 'lockout_user_test', all with timestamps.

required_data: A dedicated test user account with a known password.
test_data.test_environment: Staging environment.
test_data.data_cleanup: Administrator must unlock the 'lockout_user_test' account after the test.

prerequisites: A test user 'lockout_user_test' exists and is active.
The account lockout policy is configured to 5 attempts in the system settings.

expected_results.primary_result: The user account is locked after 5 failed login attempts and cannot be accessed even with the correct password.
verification_criteria: The system prevents login after the 5th failed attempt.
The user account status is shown as 'Locked' in the admin console.
Audit logs correctly record the failed attempts and the lockout event.

pass_criteria: Account is locked on the 5th failed attempt.
A 6th attempt with the correct password fails.
The lockout event is correctly logged.
fail_criteria: The account is not locked after 5 failed attempts.
The user can log in with the correct password on the 6th attempt.
The lockout event is not recorded in the audit log.
post_conditions: The test account 'lockout_user_test' is in a locked state.

regulatory_requirements: HIPAA Security Rule § 164.308(a)(5)(ii)(D) - Password management
NIST SP 800-63B Section 5.1.5 - Authenticator Brute Force Resistance
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Screenshots of the error messages on the 5th and 6th attempts. Screenshot of the locked account status in the admin UI. Exported audit log showing the sequence of events.

test_cases.title: Verify Audit Log Generation for PHI Access and Modification
test_cases.description: This test case verifies that when a user accesses or modifies Protected Health Information (PHI), a detailed, time-stamped audit log is created. This is a core requirement for HIPAA and FDA 21 CFR Part 11 compliance.

test_steps.expected_result: The audit log viewer is displayed.

test_steps.action: Log out and log in as a clinical user (e.g., 'Dr.Test').
test_steps.expected_result: Successful login for 'Dr.Test'.

test_steps.action: Search for and open a specific patient's record.
test_steps.expected_result: The patient's chart is displayed. This constitutes a 'read' access event.

test_steps.action: Modify a field in the patient's record, for example, update the patient's address.
test_steps.input_data: Address: '123 Main St' changed to '456 Oak Ave'.
test_steps.expected_result: The change is saved successfully. This constitutes a 'modify' or 'update' event.

test_steps.action: Log out as 'Dr.Test' and log back in as the administrator.
test_steps.expected_result: Successful login for the administrator.

test_steps.action: Navigate to the audit log viewer and filter for events related to user 'Dr.Test' and patient 'MRN-AUDIT-01' since the time noted in Step 1.
test_steps.expected_result: At least two new log entries are found: one for viewing the record and one for modifying it. The modification log must contain the user ID ('Dr.Test'), timestamp, action type ('Update'), patient ID ('MRN-AUDIT-01'), the specific field changed ('Address'), the old value ('123 Main St'), and the new value ('456 Oak Ave').

test_data.test_environment: Staging environment.
test_data.data_cleanup: Revert the address change for patient 'MRN-AUDIT-01'.

prerequisites: An administrator user and a clinical user exist.
A test patient record exists in the system.

expected_results.primary_result: All access and modification events for PHI are accurately recorded in the audit trail with all required details.
verification_criteria: An audit entry is created for viewing PHI.
An audit entry is created for modifying PHI.
The modification log includes user, timestamp, action, record ID, field name, old value, and new value.

pass_criteria: Both the read and update actions generate distinct, accurate audit log entries.
The update log contains all specified details (who, what, when, what changed).
fail_criteria: No audit log is generated for either action.
The audit log is missing critical information (e.g., user ID, timestamp, old/new values).
post_conditions: Test data changes are reverted.

regulatory_requirements: HIPAA Security Rule § 164.312(b) - Audit Controls

FDA 21 CFR Part 11.10(e) - Use of secure, computer-generated, time-stamped audit trails to independently record the date and time of operator entries and actions that create, modify, or delete electronic records.
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Exported section of the audit log showing the relevant entries. Screenshots of the patient record before and after the change, and a screenshot of the corresponding audit log entries.

test_cases.title: Verify Audit Log Immutability
test_cases.description: This test case attempts to tamper with audit logs to verify they are immutable. This ensures the integrity of the audit trail, a critical requirement for regulatory compliance and forensic analysis.

test_steps.action: Perform a simple, auditable action, such as logging in as a test user.
test_steps.expected_result: Successful login. An audit log for this event is generated.

test_steps.action: As a system administrator, attempt to delete the login audit log entry from Step 1 through the application's UI.
test_steps.input_data: Navigate to audit log viewer, select the log entry.
test_steps.expected_result: The application UI does not provide any function (e.g., a 'delete' button) to remove individual audit log entries. All such controls are disabled or absent.

test_steps.action: Gain direct access to the database where audit logs are stored.
test_steps.expected_result: Successful connection to the database.

test_steps.action: Attempt to execute a SQL DELETE statement to remove the audit log entry generated in Step 1.
test_steps.input_data: SQL: DELETE FROM audit_logs WHERE user_id = 'tamper_test_user';
test_steps.expected_result: The DELETE operation fails. The database returns an error indicating a lack of permissions, a trigger preventing deletion, or a similar protection mechanism.

test_steps.action: Attempt to execute a SQL UPDATE statement to alter the details of the audit log entry (e.g., change the user ID).
test_steps.input_data: SQL: UPDATE audit_logs SET user_id = 'another_user' WHERE event_id = [ID from Step 1];
test_steps.expected_result: The UPDATE operation fails with a permission error or is blocked by a database trigger.

test_steps.action: If logs are stored as files, attempt to modify or delete the log file directly on the server's file system.
test_steps.expected_result: The action fails due to file permissions (e.g., append-only flag). If the file is modified, a separate integrity check mechanism (e.g., a monitoring service checking file hashes) should generate an alert.

test_data.test_environment: Staging environment with full backend access.
test_data.data_cleanup: No data cleanup needed as all modifications should fail.

prerequisites: A test user account exists.
The location of audit logs (database table or file path) is known.

expected_results.primary_result: All attempts to modify or delete audit logs through any interface (UI, database, file system) are blocked and/or generate an alert.
verification_criteria: No 'delete' or 'edit' functionality for logs exists in the UI.
Direct database modification attempts fail.
Direct file system modification attempts fail or trigger an integrity alert.

pass_criteria: All attempts to tamper with the audit log are unsuccessful.
fail_criteria: An audit log entry can be successfully modified or deleted through any means without generating a separate, high-priority alert.
post_conditions: The integrity of the audit log remains intact.

regulatory_requirements: FDA 21 CFR Part 11.10(e) - Ensuring that audit trails are secure and cannot be altered.
HIPAA Security Rule § 164.312(c)(2) - Protection from alteration or destruction (Integrity).
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Screenshots of the UI showing no modification options. Screenshots of the command line showing failed SQL DELETE/UPDATE commands with error messages. A signed test execution report detailing the attempts and failures.

test_steps.action: On Day 2, after the scheduled backup time (e.g., at 9:00 AM), log in as a system administrator.
test_steps.expected_result: Successful login.

test_steps.action: Navigate to the backup management console or log directory.
test_steps.expected_result: Backup management interface is displayed.

test_steps.action: Verify that a new backup file was created with a timestamp corresponding to approximately 2:00 AM on Day 2.
test_steps.expected_result: A new backup file exists (e.g., 'backup-YYYY-MM-DD-0200.bak').

test_steps.action: Verify that the backup is stored in a geographically separate location from the primary server.

expected_results.primary_result: A valid, integrity-checked backup is created automatically at the scheduled time and stored in a remote location.
verification_criteria: A backup file is created daily around 2:00 AM.

test_cases.title: Verify System Restore from Backup within 4-hour RTO
test_cases.description: This test case simulates a catastrophic data loss and verifies that the system can be fully restored from the latest valid backup within the 4-hour Recovery Time Objective (RTO).

test_steps.action: Identify a unique data point created just before the last successful backup (e.g., patient 'BACKUP-TEST-01' from TC-REQ-004-01).
test_steps.expected_result: The data point is confirmed to exist in the live system.

test_steps.action: Create another unique data point after the last backup was taken.
test_steps.expected_result: Patient record is successfully created.

test_steps.action: Simulate a data loss event by deleting the main database or critical data tables. Start a timer to track the RTO.
test_steps.expected_result: The application becomes non-functional, returning errors when trying to access patient data. The timer is started.

test_steps.action: Initiate the documented disaster recovery procedure to restore the system from the last known good backup.
test_steps.expected_result: The restore process begins.

test_steps.action: Once the restore process is complete, stop the timer.
test_steps.expected_result: The elapsed time is recorded. The system is reported as operational.

test_steps.action: Verify the elapsed time is less than 4 hours.
test_steps.expected_result: The total time from data loss to restoration is under the 4-hour RTO.

test_steps.action: Log in to the restored application and verify data integrity.
test_steps.expected_result: The patient record 'BACKUP-TEST-01' (created before the backup) exists. The patient record 'DATA-LOSS-TEST-02' (created after the backup) does NOT exist, which is the correct behavior for a point-in-time restore.

test_data.test_environment: A dedicated staging environment that can be safely destroyed and rebuilt.
test_data.data_cleanup: The environment is considered restored to its pre-test state (minus the intentionally lost data).

prerequisites: A full, valid backup of the system is available.
A documented Disaster Recovery Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) exists.

expected_results.primary_result: The system is successfully restored from a backup, and the total downtime is within the 4-hour RTO.
verification_criteria: The restore process completes successfully.
Total time is less than 4 hours.
Data from the time of the backup is present and correct in the restored system.

pass_criteria: System is restored within 4 hours.
Data is consistent with the state at the time of the last backup.
fail_criteria: Restore process takes longer than 4 hours.
Restore process fails.
Restored data is corrupt or incomplete.
post_conditions: The test environment is restored to a functional state.

regulatory_requirements: HIPAA Security Rule § 164.308(a)(7)(i) - Contingency Plan (Required)
HIPAA Security Rule § 164.308(a)(7)(ii)(B) - Restoration of any lost data (Required)
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: A signed test execution report detailing the timeline of the test: start time of data loss, start time of recovery, end time of recovery. Total time calculated. Screenshots verifying the data state before and after the restore.

test_cases.title: Verify Drug-Drug Interaction Alert
test_cases.description: This test case verifies that the Clinical Decision Support (CDS) system generates a critical alert when a clinician attempts to prescribe a medication that has a known severe interaction with a patient's existing medication.

test_steps.action: Log in as a clinician and open the chart for a test patient.
test_steps.expected_result: Patient chart is displayed.

test_steps.action: Ensure the patient has an active prescription for Warfarin.
test_steps.input_data: Navigate to medication list, add 'Warfarin 5mg daily' if not present.
test_steps.expected_result: The patient's active medication list includes Warfarin.

test_steps.action: Navigate to the 'New Prescription' or 'e-Prescribe' module.
test_steps.expected_result: The new prescription interface is displayed.

test_steps.action: Attempt to prescribe a new medication known to have a severe interaction with Warfarin, such as 'Amiodarone'.
test_steps.expected_result: Before the prescription can be finalized, a prominent, clear, and interruptive alert is displayed on the screen.

test_steps.action: Inspect the content of the alert.

test_steps.action: Check the audit log for the alert event.
test_steps.expected_result: An audit log entry is created that records the triggering of the CDS alert, including patient ID, drugs involved, and the alert details.

test_data.data_cleanup: Remove Warfarin and any pending Amiodarone prescriptions from the test patient's record.

The drug interaction database is up-to-date.
A test patient exists in the system.

expected_results.primary_result: A severe drug-drug interaction alert is correctly triggered and displayed to the user with actionable information.
verification_criteria: An alert is displayed when prescribing Amiodarone to a patient on Warfarin.
The alert content is accurate and informative.
The alert event is logged in the audit trail.

pass_criteria: A clear, interruptive alert is displayed containing all required information.
fail_criteria: No alert is displayed.

The alert content is incorrect or incomplete.

post_conditions: Test medications are removed from the patient's chart.

test_cases.title: Verify Query Response Time Under Normal Load

test_steps.expected_result: The test script is configured and ready to run.

test_steps.action: Start the performance test script.
test_steps.expected_result: The script begins executing, simulating 50 users interacting with the system.

test_steps.action: Let the test run for a sustained period (e.g., 30 minutes).
test_steps.expected_result: The test completes after 30 minutes.

test_steps.action: Analyze the results from the performance testing tool, focusing on the transaction 'Open Patient Chart'.

test_steps.action: Using a data generation tool, insert a fake audit log entry into the audit log database table with a timestamp from 7.5 years ago.
test_steps.input_data: SQL INSERT statement for the audit_logs table with a historical timestamp.
test_steps.expected_result: The historical audit log entry is successfully inserted.

test_steps.action: Log in as an administrator with access to the audit log viewer.
test_steps.expected_result: Successful login.

test_steps.action: In the audit log viewer, set the date range to search for logs from 7.5 years ago.
test_steps.input_data: Start Date: [Current Date - 8 years], End Date: [Current Date - 7 years].
test_steps.expected_result: The audit log viewer successfully retrieves and displays the historical audit log entry created in Step 1.

test_steps.action: Review the system's data archival or purging configuration for audit logs.
test_steps.input_data: Check system settings or configuration files.
test_steps.expected_result: The configuration confirms that audit logs are set to be retained for a minimum of 7 years (or are never purged).

required_data: Database access to insert historical data.
test_data.test_environment: Staging environment.
test_data.data_cleanup: Manually delete the fake historical audit log entry from the database.

prerequisites: The ability to insert data with past timestamps into the audit log table is required.

expected_results.primary_result: Audit logs are retained and accessible for the required 7-year period.
verification_criteria: An audit log entry from over 7 years ago can be retrieved through the application UI.
System configuration for audit log retention is set to 7 years or more.

pass_criteria: The historical audit log is found and displayed correctly.
fail_criteria: The historical audit log cannot be found, indicating it has been purged prematurely.
The UI does not allow searching for logs that old.
post_conditions: The test audit log entry is removed.

regulatory_requirements: HIPAA Security Rule § 164.316(b)(2)(i) - Documentation of actions, activities, or assessments must be retained for 6 years from the date of its creation or the date when it last was in effect, whichever is later. 7 years is a common, safer industry practice.
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Screenshot of the audit log viewer displaying the 7.5-year-old log entry. Screenshot of the system's retention policy configuration for audit logs.

test_cases.title: Verify Electronic Signature Application and Linking
test_cases.description: This test case verifies that an electronic signature can be applied to a record and is securely linked to that record, in compliance with FDA 21 CFR Part 11 requirements.

test_steps.action: Log in as a user with authority to sign records (e.g., a physician).
test_steps.expected_result: Successful login.

test_steps.action: Create a new electronic record that requires a signature, such as a clinical note or a prescription.
test_steps.input_data: Create a new note for patient 'CFR-PATIENT-11' with text 'Patient seen for follow-up.'
test_steps.expected_result: The note is created in a 'Draft' or 'Unsigned' state.

test_steps.action: Initiate the 'Sign' action for the newly created record.
test_steps.expected_result: A dialog box appears, requiring the user to re-authenticate by entering their password. The dialog should also display the meaning of the signature (e.g., 'I am the author and I approve this note').

test_steps.action: Enter the correct password and click 'Sign'.
test_steps.expected_result: The system accepts the signature. The record's status changes to 'Signed' or 'Finalized'. The record becomes read-only and cannot be edited.

test_steps.action: View the signed record.
test_steps.expected_result: The record is displayed with a clear indication that it has been electronically signed, including the printed name of the signer ('Dr. Signer'), the date and time of the signature, and the meaning of the signature.

test_steps.action: Check the audit trail for the record.
test_steps.input_data: View audit history for the note.
test_steps.expected_result: An audit entry exists for the 'Sign' event, recording the user, timestamp, and a reference to the specific record version that was signed.

required_data: A user account with signing privileges.
test_data.test_environment: Staging environment.
test_data.data_cleanup: The created note can be left as test evidence or voided if functionality exists.

prerequisites: A user with signing authority has been configured.

expected_results.primary_result: An electronic record is successfully signed, with the signature cryptographically and logically linked to the record, and the event is audited.
verification_criteria: User must re-authenticate to sign.
The signed record becomes read-only.
The signature details (name, date/time, meaning) are displayed as part of the record.
The signature event is captured in the audit trail.

pass_criteria: All verification criteria are met.
fail_criteria: The system does not require re-authentication to sign.
The signed record can still be edited.
The signature information is not permanently linked to the record.
The signature event is not audited.
post_conditions: A signed electronic record exists in the system.

regulatory_requirements: FDA 21 CFR Part 11.50 - Signature manifestations.
FDA 21 CFR Part 11.70 - Signature/record linking.
FDA 21 CFR Part 11.200 - Electronic signature components and controls.
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Screenshot of the re-authentication dialog. Screenshot of the final, signed record showing the signature manifestation. Exported audit log for the signing event.

test_cases.title: Verify Secure, Time-stamped Audit Trail for Electronic Records
test_cases.description: This test case verifies that all actions on an electronic record (creation, modification, deletion) are captured in a secure, computer-generated, time-stamped audit trail as required by FDA 21 CFR Part 11.

test_steps.action: Log in as a clinical user and create a new electronic record (e.g., a medication order).
test_steps.input_data: User: 'clinician_test', Patient: 'CFR-PATIENT-11', Action: Create order for 'Lisinopril 10mg'.
test_steps.expected_result: The medication order is created successfully.

test_steps.action: Modify the created record.
test_steps.input_data: Change the dose of the Lisinopril order from '10mg' to '20mg'.
test_steps.expected_result: The medication order is updated successfully.

test_steps.action: Delete/discontinue the created record.
test_steps.expected_result: The medication order is marked as discontinued.

test_steps.action: Log in as an administrator and navigate to the audit trail viewer for the specific record or patient.
test_steps.expected_result: The audit trail for the record is displayed.

test_steps.action: Verify the audit trail contains entries for all actions performed.
test_steps.expected_result: There are three distinct entries: 1) 'Create' event, 2) 'Modify' event, 3) 'Delete/Discontinue' event. Each entry is computer-generated (no manual entry) and has a secure, non-editable timestamp.

test_steps.action: Inspect the details of the 'Modify' event log.
test_steps.input_data: Click to expand the 'Modify' log entry.
test_steps.expected_result: The log entry clearly shows the old value ('10mg') and the new value ('20mg') for the 'dose' field, along with the user ID ('clinician_test') and the exact timestamp of the change.

test_data.test_environment: Staging environment.
test_data.data_cleanup: No cleanup required, the audited events are the test evidence.

prerequisites: Clinical and admin user accounts exist.

expected_results.primary_result: A complete, accurate, and secure audit trail is maintained for the entire lifecycle of an electronic record.
verification_criteria: Create, modify, and delete actions are all logged.
Timestamps are secure and computer-generated.
Modification logs include old and new values.
The user performing the action is correctly identified.

pass_criteria: All verification criteria are met.
fail_criteria: Any action (create, modify, delete) is not logged.
The audit log is missing key details like old/new values or user ID.
Timestamps can be altered or are not present.
post_conditions: An electronic record with a full audit history exists for review.

regulatory_requirements: FDA 21 CFR Part 11.10(e) - Use of secure, computer-generated, time-stamped audit trails to independently record the date and time of operator entries and actions that create, modify, or delete electronic records.
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Exported audit trail for the specific test record. Screenshots of each step (creation, modification, deletion) and the corresponding final audit trail view.

test_cases.title: Verify Traceability from Requirement to Verification
test_cases.description: This process audit verifies that complete traceability is maintained from a specific software requirement through design, implementation, and verification, as mandated by IEC 62304.

test_steps.action: Select a safety-critical software requirement from the Software Requirements Specification (SRS).
test_steps.input_data: Requirement REQ-005: Clinical Decision Support for Drug Interactions.
test_steps.expected_result: The requirement is identified.

test_steps.action: Access the requirements traceability matrix (RTM) or the Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) tool (e.g., Jira, Azure DevOps).
test_steps.expected_result: The RTM/ALM tool is accessible.

test_steps.action: In the RTM/ALM, locate REQ-005 and trace it forward to its corresponding software architecture and design specifications.
test_steps.expected_result: REQ-005 is linked to specific design documents or diagrams (e.g., 'CDS Module Design Spec', 'Drug Interaction API Spec') that detail how the feature will be implemented.

test_steps.action: From the design specification, trace forward to the source code units/modules that implement the feature.
test_steps.input_data: Trace links from the design spec.
test_steps.expected_result: The design spec is linked to specific source code files or pull requests (e.g., 'DrugInteractionService.java', 'CDSAlertController.cs').

test_steps.action: From the source code, trace to the unit tests that verify the code modules.
test_steps.expected_result: Unit test files (e.g., 'DrugInteractionServiceTests.java') exist and have a clear relationship to the source code.

test_steps.action: Trace back from the original requirement (REQ-005) to the software verification test cases that test its functionality at the system level.
test_steps.expected_result: REQ-005 is linked to specific system test cases, such as 'TC-REQ-005-01' and 'TC-REQ-005-02'.

test_steps.action: Verify that all links are present and the traceability is complete in both directions (forward and backward).
test_steps.input_data: Review the entire chain in the ALM tool.
test_steps.expected_result: A complete, unbroken chain of traceability exists: Requirement -> Design -> Code -> Unit Test -> System Test.

required_data: Access to the ALM tool (Jira, etc.)
Access to the source code repository
test_data.test_environment: N/A (Documentation and process review).
test_data.data_cleanup: No data cleanup required.

prerequisites: The project's ALM/traceability tool is up to date.
All development artifacts (requirements, design, code, tests) are stored in managed systems.

expected_results.primary_result: Full, bi-directional traceability is demonstrated for a critical software requirement.
verification_criteria: The requirement is linked to design artifacts.
Design artifacts are linked to code.
The requirement is linked to verification test cases.

pass_criteria: An unbroken traceability chain is confirmed.
fail_criteria: Any link in the traceability chain is missing.
Traceability cannot be established from requirement to test case.
post_conditions: Compliance with IEC 62304 traceability requirements is documented.

regulatory_requirements: IEC 62304 - Section 5.1 Software development planning (requires planning for traceability).
IEC 62304 - Section 5.2.3 Content of the software requirements specification (requires traceability).
ISO 13485 - Section 7.3 Design and Development (requires traceability throughout).
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Screenshots from the ALM tool showing the linked items for REQ-005. An exported traceability report for REQ-005. A signed audit report.

test_cases.title: Verify Risk Management for a Safety-Critical Feature
test_cases.description: This process audit reviews the risk management file to verify that risks associated with a safety-critical feature have been identified, evaluated, and that risk control measures have been implemented and verified, per IEC 62304 and ISO 14971.

test_steps.action: Select a safety-critical feature, such as the Clinical Decision Support for Drug Interactions (related to REQ-005).
test_steps.expected_result: The feature is identified.

test_steps.action: Access the project's Risk Management File.
test_steps.input_data: Location of the Risk Management File (document or ALM section).
test_steps.expected_result: The file is opened.

test_steps.action: Locate the risk analysis for the selected feature. Identify a specific hazardous situation.
test_steps.input_data: Search for risks related to 'drug interaction'.
test_steps.expected_result: A hazardous situation is identified, e.g., 'System fails to alert clinician of a known severe drug-drug interaction, leading to patient harm'.

test_steps.action: Review the risk evaluation for this hazard. Note the initial risk level (severity and probability).
test_steps.expected_result: The initial risk is evaluated as 'High' or 'Unacceptable'.

test_steps.action: Identify the risk control measures defined to mitigate this risk.
test_steps.input_data: Look at the 'Risk Control Measures' column.
test_steps.expected_result: Control measures are listed, such as: '1. Implement an interruptive alert in the UI. 2. Ensure the drug knowledge base is up-to-date. 3. Log all alerts for review.'

test_steps.action: Verify that these risk control measures have been implemented. Trace the control measures to specific software requirements.
test_steps.input_data: Trace links from the risk file.
test_steps.expected_result: The control measures are linked to requirements like REQ-005 ('Drug interaction checking is performed') and REQ-003 ('All alerts are logged').

test_steps.action: Verify that the effectiveness of the risk control measures has been tested. Trace to verification activities.
test_steps.input_data: Trace links from the risk file or requirements.
test_steps.expected_result: The control measures are linked to test cases that prove their effectiveness, such as 'TC-REQ-005-01' (Verify Drug-Drug Interaction Alert).

test_steps.action: Review the residual risk evaluation.
test_steps.input_data: Review the risk assessment table/matrix after controls.
test_steps.expected_result: The residual risk is evaluated and deemed 'Acceptable' (e.g., 'Low').

required_data: Access to the Risk Management File
test_data.test_environment: N/A (Documentation and process review).
test_data.data_cleanup: No data cleanup required.

prerequisites: A Risk Management File compliant with ISO 14971 has been maintained throughout the lifecycle.

expected_results.primary_result: A complete risk management process is demonstrated for a safety-critical feature, from hazard identification to verification of control measures and acceptance of residual risk.
verification_criteria: Risks are identified and evaluated.
Risk control measures are defined and implemented.
The implementation and effectiveness of control measures are verified by testing.
Residual risk is evaluated and accepted.

pass_criteria: All verification criteria are met, showing a closed-loop risk management process.
fail_criteria: A known hazard is not documented.
A risk control measure is not defined for a high risk.
A defined risk control measure has not been verified through testing.
Residual risk is not evaluated or is unacceptable.
post_conditions: Compliance with IEC 62304 risk management requirements is documented.

regulatory_requirements: IEC 62304 - Section 7: Software risk management process.
ISO 14971 - Application of risk management to medical devices.
ISO 13485 - Section 7.1 Planning of product realization (requires risk management).
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: A copy or screenshot of the relevant sections of the Risk Management File. A signed audit report summarizing the findings.

test_cases.title: Audit Change Control Process in QMS
test_cases.description: This process audit verifies that a recent software change was managed according to the documented Change Control procedure within the ISO 13485 compliant Quality Management System (QMS).

test_steps.action: Select a recently implemented software change. This could be a bug fix or a new feature.
test_steps.input_data: Example: Change Request #CR-105 - 'Add allergy reaction field'.
test_steps.expected_result: A specific change request is identified.

test_steps.action: Retrieve the organization's official Change Control Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) from the QMS.
test_steps.expected_result: The Change Control SOP is obtained.

test_steps.action: Access the QMS records for CR-105 (e.g., in Jira, a dedicated QMS software).
test_steps.expected_result: The complete record for the change request is displayed.

test_steps.action: Verify that the change request includes an evaluation of the change, including its impact on safety, risk, and regulatory requirements, as required by the SOP.
test_steps.input_data: Review the 'Impact Analysis' section of CR-105.
test_steps.expected_result: The impact analysis is filled out and approved.

test_steps.action: Verify that the change was reviewed and approved by the required personnel (e.g., QA, Regulatory, Clinical Safety Officer) before implementation, as defined in the SOP.
test_steps.expected_result: The record shows electronic signatures or documented approval from all required roles.

test_steps.action: Verify that verification and validation activities were planned and executed for the change.
test_steps.input_data: Review the 'Testing' or 'V&V' section of CR-105.
test_steps.expected_result: The change record is linked to new or updated test cases, and the test execution results are attached or linked, showing a 'Pass' status.

test_steps.action: Verify that all activities are documented and traceable within the QMS, as required by the SOP.
test_steps.expected_result: All steps from initiation to closure are documented in the change record, creating a complete audit trail for the change.

required_data: Access to the QMS document control system
Access to the change management system (e.g., Jira).
test_data.test_environment: N/A (Documentation and process review).
test_data.data_cleanup: No data cleanup required.

prerequisites: A QMS compliant with ISO 13485 is in place.
A documented Change Control SOP exists and is enforced.

expected_results.primary_result: The selected software change is confirmed to have followed the established change control procedure from initiation to closure.
verification_criteria: The change was formally requested and documented.
Impact analysis was performed.
Required approvals were obtained prior to implementation.
Verification and validation were performed and documented.

pass_criteria: The documented evidence for the change request aligns with the requirements of the Change Control SOP.
fail_criteria: Any mandatory step in the SOP was skipped (e.g., no approval, no V&V).
Documentation for the change is incomplete or missing.
post_conditions: Compliance with ISO 13485 change control requirements is documented.

regulatory_requirements: ISO 13485 - Section 7.3.9 Control of design and development changes.
IEC 62304 - Section 6: Software maintenance process.
FDA 21 CFR 820.30(i) - Design changes.
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: A copy of the Change Control SOP. Screenshots or a PDF export of the complete change request record (CR-105) from the QMS. A signed audit report.

test_cases.title: Verify Configuration Management Procedures
test_cases.description: This process audit verifies that the software components of a specific release are under configuration management, ensuring that the released version is built from the correct, approved versions of all source code and other items.

test_steps.action: Select a specific, recent software release for audit.
test_steps.expected_result: The release version is identified.

test_steps.action: Retrieve the Software Configuration Management Plan from the QMS.
test_steps.expected_result: The plan document is obtained.

test_steps.action: Retrieve the Bill of Materials (BOM) or list of configuration items for release 2.1.0.
test_steps.input_data: Release notes or configuration management records.
test_steps.expected_result: A list of all software items (e.g., application source code, libraries, SOUP) and their specific versions for release 2.1.0 is obtained.

test_steps.action: For the main application source code, verify that release 2.1.0 corresponds to a specific, immutable tag in the source code repository (e.g., Git).
test_steps.expected_result: A tag named 'v2.1.0' exists in the Git repository. The commit hash associated with the tag can be identified.

test_steps.action: Verify that any third-party libraries or Software of Unknown Provenance (SOUP) listed in the BOM have their exact versions specified.
test_steps.input_data: Review the BOM and compare with dependency files (e.g., pom.xml, package.json).
test_steps.expected_result: The versions match exactly (e.g., 'log4j version 2.17.1', not 'log4j version 2.x').

test_steps.action: Verify that the build script or CI/CD pipeline configuration used to create the release 2.1.0 binary is also under version control.
test_steps.input_data: Check repository for build files (e.g., Jenkinsfile, azure-pipelines.yml).
test_steps.expected_result: The build configuration is versioned and its state for release 2.1.0 can be determined.

test_data.test_environment: N/A (Documentation and process review).
test_data.data_cleanup: No data cleanup required.

prerequisites: A QMS is in place.
A documented Software Configuration Management Plan exists.

expected_results.primary_result: The exact configuration of a software release is identifiable and reproducible from version-controlled items.
verification_criteria: The release corresponds to a unique tag in the source code repository.
All components, including SOUP, have their exact versions documented.
The build process itself is version controlled.

pass_criteria: All verification criteria are met.
fail_criteria: The release was not built from a tagged version of the code.
SOUP versions are not explicitly defined.
The build process cannot be reliably reproduced.
post_conditions: Compliance with IEC 62304 configuration management requirements is documented.

regulatory_requirements: IEC 62304 - Section 8: Software configuration management process.
ISO 13485 - Section 4.2.3 Control of documents & 4.2.4 Control of records.
FDA 21 CFR 820.30(j) - Design history file (DHF).
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Screenshot of the Git tag for the release. A copy of the software BOM for the release. A signed audit report.

test_cases.title: Verify ISMS Risk Treatment Implementation
test_cases.description: This test case audits the Information Security Management System (ISMS) to verify that a security control, identified as part of a risk treatment plan, has been correctly implemented and is effective.

test_steps.action: Access the ISMS documentation, specifically the Risk Assessment and Risk Treatment Plan.
test_steps.expected_result: The documents are accessible.

test_steps.action: Identify a high-risk item from the risk assessment.
test_steps.input_data: Example risk: 'Unauthorized access to production database containing PHI'.
test_steps.expected_result: The risk and its high rating are located in the risk register.

test_steps.action: Find the corresponding risk treatment plan for this risk. Identify a specific control to be implemented.
test_steps.input_data: Example control from treatment plan: 'Implement database activity monitoring (DAM) to alert on suspicious queries'. This control maps to ISO 27001 Annex A.12.4.1 Event logging.
test_steps.expected_result: The control is identified in the treatment plan.

test_steps.action: Request evidence that this control has been implemented.
test_steps.input_data: Ask the infrastructure team for access to or a demonstration of the DAM tool.
test_steps.expected_result: Access is provided to the DAM tool's console (e.g., Guardium, Imperva).

test_steps.action: Verify the control is active and configured correctly. Check that it is monitoring the production database and has alert rules configured.
test_steps.expected_result: The production database is listed as a monitored target. Alert rules for actions like 'SELECT * from patients' or 'access from an unauthorized IP' are active.

test_steps.action: Test the effectiveness of the control by performing a (pre-approved) suspicious action and verifying that an alert is generated.
test_steps.input_data: From a non-standard IP, attempt to run a query that should trigger an alert.
test_steps.expected_result: An alert is generated in the DAM console and/or sent to the security team's notification channel (e.g., email, Slack) within minutes.

test_data.test_environment: Production monitoring tools (read-only access) and a staging database for the active test.
test_data.data_cleanup: Acknowledge and close the test alert.

prerequisites: An ISMS compliant with ISO 27001 is established.
A risk assessment and treatment plan exist.

expected_results.primary_result: A security control defined in the risk treatment plan is confirmed to be implemented, configured correctly, and effective.
verification_criteria: The control is implemented as a technical solution (DAM tool).
The control is configured to monitor the correct assets.
The control effectively generates an alert when triggered.

pass_criteria: All verification criteria are met.
fail_criteria: The control has not been implemented.
The control is implemented but misconfigured (e.g., not monitoring the production DB).
The control fails to generate an alert during a test.
post_conditions: The effectiveness of a key security control is documented.

regulatory_requirements: ISO 27001 - Clause 6.1.3 Information security risk treatment.
ISO 27001 - Clause 8.3 Information security risk treatment.
HIPAA Security Rule § 164.308(a)(1)(ii)(A) - Risk Analysis.
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Excerpt from the risk treatment plan. Screenshot of the DAM tool configuration. Screenshot of the generated alert. A signed audit report.

test_cases.title: Verify Security Control Enforcement (Access Control)
test_cases.description: This test verifies that a specific access control from the ISO 27001 Statement of Applicability (SoA) is correctly implemented and enforced by the system.

test_steps.action: Access the ISMS Statement of Applicability (SoA).
test_steps.expected_result: The SoA document is opened.

test_steps.action: Identify a specific, testable access control.
test_steps.input_data: Control: A.9.2.3 Management of privileged access rights. Implementation detail: 'Privileged access rights are restricted to the minimum necessary for the role (principle of least privilege).'
test_steps.expected_result: The control and its implementation method are identified.

test_steps.action: Select a user role that should have limited, non-privileged access.
test_steps.expected_result: A test user with this role is identified or created.

test_steps.action: Log in as the 'billing_clerk_test' user.
test_steps.expected_result: Successful login. The user sees a dashboard tailored to the billing role.

test_steps.action: Attempt to access a privileged function, such as the system's user management page, by directly navigating to its URL.
test_steps.expected_result: Access is denied. The user is redirected to the dashboard or an 'Access Denied' page. An HTTP 403 Forbidden error is returned.

test_steps.action: Attempt to access clinical data that is not required for billing, such as a patient's clinical notes, by navigating to the URL.
test_steps.expected_result: Access is denied. The system enforces the access control policy and prevents the user from viewing the data.

test_steps.action: Check the audit log for these failed access attempts.
test_steps.expected_result: The audit log contains entries for user 'billing_clerk_test' showing 'Unauthorized Access Attempt' for the admin and clinical notes URLs.

required_data: A test user with a non-privileged role.
test_data.test_environment: Staging environment.
test_data.data_cleanup: No cleanup required.

prerequisites: Role-based access control is implemented.
A test user with a limited role exists.

expected_results.primary_result: The system correctly enforces the principle of least privilege, preventing a user from accessing functions and data outside their authorized role.
verification_criteria: User cannot access privileged administrative pages.
User cannot access unauthorized clinical data.
Failed access attempts are logged.

pass_criteria: All attempts to access unauthorized resources are blocked.
fail_criteria: The user is able to access any page or data for which they are not authorized.
post_conditions: The effectiveness of the access control is verified.

regulatory_requirements: ISO 27001 - Annex A.9.2.3 Management of privileged access rights.
HIPAA Security Rule § 164.308(a)(4)(ii)(C) - Access Control and Validation Procedures.
compliance_validation.validation_evidence: Screenshots of the 'Access Denied' pages. Exported audit log showing the failed access attempts. A reference to the SoA control being tested.

test_cases.title: Verify HIPAA Technical Safeguards (Access Control & Audit)
test_cases.description: This test case verifies the implementation of key HIPAA Technical Safeguards, specifically Unique User Identification, Access Control, and Audit Controls, by testing a complete workflow.

test_steps.action: Log in using a unique user account assigned to a specific clinician.
test_steps.input_data: Username: 'Dr.HipaaTest', Password: 'ValidPassword123!'. This verifies Unique User Identification (§ 164.312(a)(2)(i)).
test_steps.expected_result: Successful login. The system uniquely identifies the user as 'Dr.HipaaTest'.

test_steps.action: Access a function appropriate for the clinician's role, such as opening a patient chart.
test_steps.expected_result: The system grants access, and the patient chart is displayed. This verifies the 'Access Control' safeguard (§ 164.312(a)(1)) is allowing authorized access.

test_steps.action: Attempt to access a function not appropriate for the clinician's role, such as deleting another user's account.
test_steps.input_data: Navigate to admin user management URL.
test_steps.expected_result: Access is denied. This verifies the 'Access Control' safeguard is preventing unauthorized access.

test_steps.action: Log out and log in as an administrator.
test_steps.expected_result: Successful login.

test_steps.action: Navigate to the audit log viewer and filter for the activity of user 'Dr.HipaaTest'.
test_steps.expected_result: The audit log is displayed.

test_steps.action: Verify that the user's actions have been recorded.
test_steps.expected_result: The log contains entries for: 1) Successful login, 2) Accessing patient chart 'PHI-TEST-01', and 3) Unauthorized access attempt to the admin page. This verifies the 'Audit Controls' safeguard (§ 164.312(b)).

test_data.test_environment: Staging environment.
test_data.data_cleanup: No cleanup required.

prerequisites: Role-based access control is implemented with at least a 'Clinician' and 'Administrator' role.

expected_results.primary_result: The system demonstrates compliance with fundamental HIPAA Technical Safeguards for user identification, access control, and auditing.
verification_criteria: Each user has a unique ID.
Access is granted or denied based on user role.
All access and attempted access to ePHI and system functions are logged.

pass_criteria: All verification criteria are met.
fail_criteria: Users can share accounts.
Access control is not properly enforced.
Auditing is incomplete or missing.
post_conditions: Evidence of compliance with key HIPAA safeguards is documented.

regulatory_requirements: HIPAA Security Rule § 164.312(a)(1) - Access Control

test_cases.title: Verify Remediation of a Known Vulnerability
test_cases.description: This test case verifies that a specific vulnerability, identified in a previous security assessment or penetration test, has been successfully remediated and is no longer exploitable.

test_steps.action: Obtain the report from the last penetration test or vulnerability scan.
test_steps.expected_result: The report is obtained.

test_steps.action: Select a high-risk vulnerability from the report to re-test.
test_steps.input_data: Vulnerability ID: VULN-007 - 'Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in Patient Search Field'.
test_steps.expected_result: The vulnerability details, including steps to reproduce, are understood.

test_steps.action: Access the application running the new, patched software version where the fix was supposedly implemented.
test_steps.expected_result: The application login page is displayed.

test_steps.action: Follow the original steps to reproduce the vulnerability.
test_steps.input_data: In the patient search field, enter the XSS payload from the report: `<script>alert('XSS')</script>` and click 'Search'.
test_steps.expected_result: The application handles the input without executing the script. Instead of a JavaScript alert box appearing, the search results page is displayed, and the input is either rejected with an error message or displayed as properly encoded text (e.g., showing '<script>alert('XSS')</script>' on the page).

test_steps.action: View the HTML source of the search results page.
test_steps.expected_result: The malicious script payload is found to be HTML-entity encoded and is not present as a raw script tag.

test_steps.action: Update the vulnerability tracking system to mark VULN-007 as 'Remediated' or 'Closed'.
test_steps.expected_result: The status of the vulnerability is updated, and this test case is linked as evidence of re-testing.

required_data: Access to the patched version of the application.
test_data.test_environment: A staging environment deployed with the software version that includes the vulnerability fix.
test_data.data_cleanup: Clear browser cache if needed.

prerequisites: A vulnerability has been identified and a fix has been developed and deployed to the test environment.

expected_results.primary_result: The previously identified XSS vulnerability is no longer present in the application, confirming the effectiveness of the remediation.
verification_criteria: Injecting the XSS payload does not result in script execution.
The application correctly sanitizes or encodes the malicious input.

pass_criteria: The attempt to exploit the vulnerability fails.
fail_criteria: The vulnerability is still exploitable, and the JavaScript alert box appears.
post_conditions: The remediation of the vulnerability is formally verified and documented.

regulatory_requirements: HIPAA Security Rule § 164.308(a)(1)(ii)(A) - Risk Analysis and § 164.308(a)(1)(ii)(B) - Risk Management. (Remediation is part of risk management).
ISO 27001 - Clause 12.6 Technical vulnerability management.

test_cases.title: Verify LIS Integration for Normal Lab Results

test_steps.expected_result: A valid HL7 message is created.

test_steps.action: Send the HL7 message to the application's MLLP listener endpoint.
test_steps.input_data: Send the message over the configured TCP/IP port.
test_steps.expected_result: The application's listener accepts the message and returns an HL7 ACK (acknowledgment) message indicating successful receipt.

test_steps.expected_result: Successful login.

test_steps.action: Open the chart for patient 'LIS-PATIENT-01' and navigate to the 'Lab Results' section.
test_steps.expected_result: The 'Lab Results' section is displayed.

test_steps.action: Verify that the new lab results are present and correctly displayed.
test_steps.expected_result: A new panel for 'Complete Blood Count' is present with the correct collection date/time. The individual results (WBC, RBC, etc.) are listed with their values, units, and reference ranges. Since the values were normal, there are no abnormal flags highlighted.

required_data: A valid sample HL7 ORU^R01 message.
test_data.test_environment: Staging environment with an active HL7 MLLP listener.
test_data.data_cleanup: Delete the lab results for 'LIS-PATIENT-01'.
